Line 31: Line 31:
XFS is (along with [[JFS (file system)|JFS]]) among the oldest [[journaling file system]]s available for UNIX systems, and has a mature, stable and well-debugged codebase.{{Fact|date=December 2007}} Development of XFS was started by [[Silicon Graphics]], in 1993, with first deployment being seen on IRIX 5.3 in 1994. The filesystem was released under the [[GNU General Public License]] in May 2000, and ported to Linux, with the first distribution support appearing in 2001/2002. It is available in almost all Linux distributions today, with the notable exception of Red Hat Enterprise Linux.[http://oss.sgi.com/archives/xfs/2005-08/msg00133.html]
XFS is (along with [[JFS (file system)|JFS]]) among the oldest [[journaling file system]]s available for UNIX systems, and has a mature, stable and well-debugged codebase.{{Fact|date=December 2007}} Development of XFS was started by [[Silicon Graphics]], in 1993, with first deployment being seen on IRIX 5.3 in 1994. The filesystem was released under the [[GNU General Public License]] in May 2000, and ported to Linux, with the first distribution support appearing in 2001/2002. It is available in almost all Linux distributions today, with the notable exception of Red Hat Enterprise Linux.[http://oss.sgi.com/archives/xfs/2005-08/msg00133.html]
â
XFS has been merged into the mainline [[Linux (kernel)|Linux]] 2.4 (as of 2.4.25, when [[Marcelo Tosatti]] judged it stable enough) and 2.6 kernels, making it almost universally available on Linux systems. Installation programs for the [[Arch Linux|Arch]], [[SUSE]], [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], [[Mandriva]], [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]], [[Slackware]], [[Kate OS]], [[Zenwalk]], [[VectorLinux]], [[Ubuntu Linux|Ubuntu]] and [[Debian]] [[Linux distributions]] all offer XFS as a choice of filesystem. [[FreeBSD]] gained read-only support for XFS in December 2005 and in June 2006 experimental write support was introduced; however this is supposed to be used only as an aid in migration from Linux, not to be used as a "main" filesystem.
+
XFS has been merged into the mainline [[Linux (kernel)|Linux]] 2.4 (as of 2.4.25, when [[Marcelo Tosatti]] judged it stable enough) and 2.6 kernels, making it almost universally available on Linux systems. Installation programs for the [[Arch Linux|Arch]], [[SUSE]], [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], [[Mandriva]], [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]], [[Slackware]], [[Kate OS]], [[Zenwalk]], [[VectorLinux]], [[Ubuntu Linux|Ubuntu]] and [[Debian]] [[Linux distributions]] all offer XFS as a choice of filesystem. [[FreeBSD]] gained read-only support for XFS in December 2005 and in June 2006 experimental write support was introduced; however this is supposed to be used only as an aid in migration from Linux, not to be used as a "main" filesystem.
